review_title: Overt and covert bias are insidious here
pros: Great community of BIPOC and queer colleagues
cons: Unsupportive to BIPOC if you have a white supervisor. And politics make it even harder, because BIPOC supervisors are stressed out by white supervisors above them. The stress gets to you somehow.

pros: - Attention to DEI - Friends!

job_title: Senior Program Support Assistant in Dover, NH
pros: Access to higher education for a discounted price (if you can find the time among the huge workloads).
cons: Beurocratic hoops to get even the slightest raise in pay, lots of "we just can't do that" for the people doing the most work but earning the least. Meanwhile professors who teach 2 classes and treat employees like trash make 4 times as much.

review_title: Everything was going great until they overhauled the entire IT Department laying off many
job_title: Web Developer/Web Designer in Durham, NH
pros: Low-stress, easy commute, nice people to work with, loved what I did, manager was awesome
cons: Besides being laid off, things had started to go down hill in terms of the direction of IT and was causing serious morale issues. Not sure if I'd be able to go back there even if offered a position. Different departments really treated you as if you don't even work for UNH and it was always bizarre to me. I found myself constantly wondering, "Don't we all work for the same company and aren't we all trying to achieve the same goals?" I guess the politics that happens everywhere happened there too, unless you worked in the Library which was the best place to be (unless you were in IT within the Library).

pros: There are not many pros to working there
cons: Little diversity and poor pay

job_title: Research Scientist II in Durham, NH
pros: Maternity leave and medical benefits

job_title: Research Technician III in Durham, NH

pros: nice environment and nice co workers

review_title: Great place to be an Adjunct

pros: Great entry level/middle management staff, students are great, campus is beautiful, 401K is impressive with a high match.
cons: the higher ed system is set up so those who care/work hard get taken advantage of and those who don't put in the work- have a great happy life with no consequences/ stress. burnout of staff was a huge issue and UNH isn't taking it seriously- we are all simply replaceable. It was evident to see which departments mattered most on campus and the remote/ in-person divide seemed to really divide employees. resources are not properly allocated and red tape all around to make a simple positive change.

Applicants should be wary of accepting an adjunct position in hopes that it may develop into a long-term full-time opportunity.

pros: Great benefits between health and free college courses at any of the USNH schools. I also enjoyed working on the beautiful campus, talking walks during lunch, downtown etc. Work/life balance was also great. Done at 4:30pm on the dot every day. I was lucky to have a very supportive supervisor.
cons: Salary didn’t seem competitive in comparison to other companies in the area, and it was difficult to implement change and efficiencies within the department. I did receive a raise each year but it seems like it would take you a long time to get a significant pay bump unless you make a move into a different role. Although I had a supportive supervisor and pretty solid team, there was definitely some people pretty stuck in their ways which is frustrating.

pros: This was a great job to have for the summer, especially if you are a student. The pay was good and I made a lot of friends. The work was hard but made for a good sleep at night. The management is very understanding if you need time off. I got an internship which they encouraged me to take so I worked there for part of the week.
cons: I can not think of much other than if you are put into a group of workers who don't have intention to do the job you may not have a good time. This happened and fortunately I was not in such a group but I did hear about it.

review_title: Great place to work (as long as you don't care about compensation)
pros: Great people. Great facility. Fulfilling work. Best job I've ever had in those regards.
cons: Poor compensation. No job security. Constantly dealing with budget cuts. Working there relies on state funding in a state that makes it a point not to fund things. Administrators and deans make too much relative to workers. Stringing junior teachers along with dreams of future compensation and possible tenure, which, as far as I have seen in my 5 years, has never happened for anyone.

review_title: Can’t afford to live here anymore
pros: Great people, good benefits, students are wonderful, professional development is valued and encouraged, campus is gorgeous, work/life balance is attainable
cons: I have a masters and six years of experience. I can’t afford the cost of living here anymore. My pay is lower than most entry-level jobs. Promises of advancement went out the window during COVID. To rub salt in the wound, you have to pay for parking and there was no assistance to set up a home office during COVID. Freelance is strongly discouraged. The job is wonderful but very hard to pay bills.

pros: UNH is a great place to work with so many opportunities to grow and develop new skills and career paths. UNH favors those that take the initiative to develop their career further and think outside the box. Lots of benefits and freedoms you probably won't find at any old job.
cons: HR and higher-ups will not hold your hand which can be a con for those who are looking for a place to simply clock in and collect a paycheck. Some employee resources can be a challenge to find online while others are hard to even know about unless you pay close attention and talk to colleagues. The resources and benefits are there, however, and abundantly so.

cons: Like any location, it is always growing and evolving. The good thing is they listen and actively seek the opinion of those who attend and work there.

pros:
Growth opportunities in the company

Communication in the company as a whole

Research options based on expectations

Team building across the board

Coworkers.
cons:
Schedule

Lack of travel

Small class sizes and faculty

Weather can be very cold

Funding isn't always available

pros: Great people to work with
cons: Sometimes menial work, not always a challenge

job_title: Business Services Representative in Durham, NH
pros: Amazing coworkers, great entry level position
cons: No cons to this job, I enjoyed it

pros: Quiet environment and people who really care about the arts here.
cons: During the current pandemic, many of the tours and events hosted by the Museum of Art have been cancelled, meaning that I don't have as many responsibilities and opportunity to learn during my shifts.

review_title: Great service for being a student note-taker and tutor
pros:
Just have to upload your own notes and schedule tutoring sessions
Very do it yourself and free time
Pays well
cons: Pay took a long time

review_title: Great, nicer place to work than industry lower pay, better benefits, but they are cutting benefits!
pros: The University of New Hampshire is a very NICE place to work. The atmosphere is more laid back than most industrial jobs and the people are nicer on a day to day basis.
cons:
I have worked at the University of New Hampshire for two decades and “the times, they are changing”. 
There seems to be great effort to outsource jobs to contracting firms and encourage workers to come for a while and “move on”.  
Management has the opinion: everyone (but them) are just a warm body, doing a routine job. They indicate all employees are just cogs on a wheel, interchangeable.  Management seems to think that there are no skills, just monkey routines.   The respect has gone (in both directions!).

pros: Good work life balance- I feel supported and heard by admin
cons: I wish there were more research supports, NH is not diverse...at all.

job_title: Financial Support Specialist in Durham, NH
pros: The time off/health benefits and seeing all the college kids and grant work is satisfying
cons: Uncertainty for job in the future. Can only take away from non-union folks to save money

pros: Great labs and science being done.
cons: Government funding and grant applications.

job_title: IT Project Manager in Durham, NH
pros: Flexibility and response to COVID
cons: Salary freeze and cost of benefits rising

pros: people, weather, communities, education and mountains
cons: no diversity and far from resources

pros: fun, healthy, easy, fresh, flexible
cons: NO TIPS, boring, low pay, yay mode

pros: Very Flexible scheduling options offered
cons: A lot of opportunities revoked from COVID

pros: Innovative and collaborative work environment.
cons: The University of New Hampshire suffers from an extreme lack of diversity.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Durham, NH
pros: Organized, Diversity, Cleanness, Teacher, Topic
cons: Small, Class, System, Laboratory, Campus

pros: helpful professors, a pretty campus
cons: cost is not great but welcome to law school

pros: Nice campus, good to make your own hours
cons: Annoying pay schedule and pay system

pros: Good hours, flexible, easy to learn
cons: must work on the weekends

review_title: MS Candidate in Analytics and Data Science at the University of New Hampshire (Expected May 2018)
pros:
•	The uniqueness of this program is that we take elective courses and gain knowledge and experiences in multiple disciplines while we focus mainly on data science and analytics, computer science, and team work. 
•	I am focusing on health analytics which helps us to understand the US Health care system and formulate ways to improve it.
•	The program is an interdisciplinary graduate program that offers in-depth training in quantitative analysis, applications and reasoning, decision trees, critical thinking and analytics. Throughout the program we are learning many algorithms, where we are taught to think in real-world applications as well as in new and innovative solutions to the problems presented. Machine-learning, statistical-analysis, and creative exploration are areas which I am most interested to learn about. 
•	We also gain experience with various languages like R and Python and visualization techniques like Tableau, depending on assignments and independent work and research.
cons: Right fit for the market

job_title: Assistant Research Professor in Durham, NH
pros:
It's a very pretty location.  Fall colors are awesome.  Great access to Maine and the coast.  Houses are cheap compared to most major cities.  Food service for a university is amazing.
There are a few really great programs and people hidden in the university.
cons:
Poor infrastructure: computer facilities, internet, library, physical building etc.
Unwillingness to raise my pay even though I was soft money and paying for myself.
The undergrads mostly just want to party.
When I started, the university said that they are a "Tier 1 research university."  I don't see how they justified saying that.
Much of the staff and some of the faculty have never been outside of the area for work.  That makes them slow to adopt better practices from elsewhere.
UNH receives the least amount of state funding of any state university system in the country.  And it shows.
There is definitely gender and some racial issues at the university.

review_title: It was a great place to build a strong professional skill set and felt like a strong community.
job_title: Senior Assistant Director of Admissions in Durham, NH
pros: Great community that is very supportive and lots of opportunities to work across disciplines and campus offices.  Big emphasis on professional development.  Very generous vacation time-off, lots of independence, and great colleagues.
cons: Previously, the leadership of the university lacked a clear vision which made the university seem "stuck."  however, new leadership as of 2008 has put the university on the right track.  A lot of people have worked there for awhile, so some offices can be slow to change.  It's education, so the pay isn't amazing but the benefits package and quality of life more than make up for it.

pros: UNH has a beautiful location. It is a lovely, nature-filled campus. There are many great individuals despite the disorganization and lack of communication.
cons: There is a general feeling of demoralization throughout the faculty, staff, and graduate students. Across the campus on both the academic and business sides of the university, employees complain about being overworked and being bullied by their managers. Overbearing/bullying  managers and lab PIs are allowed to stay in their positions and complaints are filed away and unacknowledged. With a few exceptions, the university collects under-achievers, especially in management, and basic competence is highly discouraged. I've known many people that have worked at UNH or were graduate students their. Only a few had positive experiences. If you are a hard working, competent, professional and expect the same from others, you will not be happy here.

pros: My supervising instructor (as well as most of the department staff) was competent and respectful.  For the most part, students were willing to learn.
cons: This really depends on the department.  For me, it was clear that at least a handful of students were in the major for the wrong reasons.  Certain professors were unprepared/disorganized.  One professor was absolutely incompetent, possibly neurotic.  I can't imagine how he got tenure.

pros: A lively center of academic activity in a pleasant setting, with a hard-working and dedicated faculty and good students
cons: Limited by the very ungenerous funding from the State of New Hampshire (lowest of the 50 states in support of the state university).    Too much money spent on building projects (e.g. 25 million renovating football stadium and business school which required a multi-million-dollar subvention)) diverts  funds from more worthy educational uses.   Increasing reliance on temporary and part-time faculty limits research and graduate programs.

review_title: Working in the Department of Fine Arts was very nice.  All models were respected by students and professors.
pros: Part-time, choose your schedule, understanding and respectful upper management, good hourly pay, enjoyable work, fits into schedule perfectly and allows for some mild flexibility in calling out sick.  Also opportunity to take extra shifts and make more money.
cons: The biggest issue that I ran into while working here was the fact that once you provided a schedule, you were basically locked into it.  Calling out was available but it was always better to avoid that.  I also found that occasionally there were some uncomfortable situations created between professors and graduate students. Otherwise an extremely comfortable job, minus the muscle cramps.

review_title: Student worker for entire educational career
pros: I worked at both the Library and the Survey Center for my time at UNH. The time at the library (3.5 years) was amazing. I worked with librarians who were interested in your personal growth and cultivation.
cons: The survey center along with many other student jobs were literally just looking for punch in, punch out employees. There was no interaction between students and no growth to be had . Thats all a shame in a university setting.

pros: Benefits are fantastic, the best in the state. Free tuition!! If you want a "large company" atmosphere where you are anonymous, can work your 8 to 4:30, and are not interested in advancement or promotions, then this is the place for you.
cons: No advancement or promotion opportunities. Again, if you want a "large company" atmosphere where you are anonymous, can work your 8 to 4:30, and not get promoted, then this is the place for you. If you are driven, motivated and want to achieve, look elsewhere. Workplace bullying does exist in some departments.

pros: Great programming helping the public.
cons: No growth path.  Managers are not concerned with employee satisfication or growth.  Toxic work culture, low morale. Comes from the top.

pros: If you get in as full time with benefits and you're a good ole boy, you'll do OK. Benefits overall are pretty good but the pay isn't good nor is it bad.
cons: If classified as a "Temp", you get no benefits whatsoever and the pay is even worse. The kicker is that they have a policy of not keeping "Temps" for more than 3 years. If close to the 3 years, get in full time or prepare to leave willingly or unwillingly.

pros: The free tuition is a terrific benefit if you are in a benefit eligible position. You can earn all the way through a doctorate degree free of charge.  Full time employees can take up to 5 classes per year. Depending on the department, management tends to be pretty flexible. I'm able to adjust my schedule, within reason, if I have a doctors appointment or car trouble, for example. They also have a terrific retirement benefit, contributing 11% to your 401k.  It's also fun to see the new students come in and watch them blossom as they move through their education.
cons: One of the major downsides has been poor leadership on multiple levels. People tend to stay here for decades and have never experienced the inner workings of a real business or another educational institution. Also, the people who run the business are academics who have rarely worked in the business environment. As a result they aren't very competative with other schools. They are slow to make decisions, partially because they are dealing with a faculty union that tends to slow things down a bit.  The faculty union is another downside if you are on the staff side of the organization.  Staff are typically not compensated as well as faculty. And some faculty tend to talk down to or think less of staff members who work just as hard, sometimes harder than faculty.

review_title: Advisor great, budget cuts not great
pros: My best reasons all stem from my advisor, who, despite being someone who is pretty laid back in terms of guiding your project, was great at always being available to meet with and giving praise for a job well done or showing initiative.
cons: Current trends in the University which include cutting back on teaching assistantships and funding for graduate students overall. There is also a lack of courses specific to graduate students. Courses which cater to both graduates and undergraduates only require a little bit of extra work to get the graduate level grade.

job_title: Resident Hall Director in Durham, NH
pros: Had a fantastic experience while working there.  The staff and CORE were amazing.  I would not trade the experience I had there for anything in the world.
cons: The pay was okay.  However, there were a lot of perks with the job.  Sometimes there was too much red tape to work through.  Not much room for mobility.

review_title: Great Opportunity for Growth and Expansion
pros: With so many opportunities in a variety of academic departments and support functions at the University of New Hampshire, it is very easy to maintain a forward-moving career without ever having to change the commute.
cons: Some of the positions have lower salaries than those of comparable commercial industries nearby in the Portsmouth and Boston markets, but the benefits package at the University of New Hampshire still beats those of the commercial industry for now.

pros: The health insurance fee is waived for the entire year you are a TA. Also, you only have to pay half of the mandatory fees while on assistantship, since you can only take a maximum of 8 credits.
cons: It is hard to find an affordable apartment in the area with the ~$15,000 salary. Rent costs are quite high in this area, especially in Durham.

job_title: Information Technologist II in Durham, NH
pros: Great coworkers, high morale, lots of great events, good pay, awesome benefits, a good amount of PTO
cons: It can be difficult to move up here as it can sometimes be who you know and not how skilled you are that lands you the interview. Change takes time (like at any large organization) as it has to go through layers of management (and lots of meetings) first.

pros:
I worked for the branch libraries (in Kingsbury, Parsons, and Demeritt).
-Wonderful managers. They are all very positive and very personal.
-The job is very relaxing. Oftentimes during evening shifts you will do library work for about an hour and then have one-two hours covering the desk and doing homework.
-You get assigned some hours but can pick a good portion of your schedule
cons: None really. The pay isn't amazing but it's nothing to complain about and definitely worth it.

job_title: Phd Candidate Mechanical Engineering in Durham, NH
pros: Good size school. The Mechanical Engineering Dept. is big enough to have the resources that you need to do substantial research, but small enough that it's not impersonal.
cons: Like with other academic institutions, sometimes it seems like things aren't managed as well as they should be.

job_title: Teaching Assistant/Software Developer (CS Department) in McKinney, TX
pros: CS Department at UNH has very friendly and helpful Faculty members and staff. The smallness of the department leads to a closer ant tighter relationship between the members. Besides, Durham is a nice and peaceful town.
cons: The size of the department in terms of research faculty  is small. This, I believe, limits the variety of research and courses going on.

pros:
If you get lucky with the residents that you have and the staff that you are on, you will have an incredible experience as an RA at UNH.

Free single room and meal plan is a huge benefit.
cons: Sometimes you can have residents that are tough to deal with and can cause your job to be very difficult.

review_title: Things are not what they seem.
pros: Great benefits.  Beautiful campus.  Students were terrific to work with.  Facilities were workable.  Got to work with some incredible people.
cons: State funded at 4%.  State constantly pulls money back so we're never really sure of what we have to work with.  Cutting of popular programs and lack of transparency while doing so.

review_title: Wonderful Job at UNH Math Center
pros: The environment at the Math Center is just like family; fellow students meet weekly for recreational card games or other activities.  The supervisors are very supportive and helpful, doing whatever it takes to make you feel comfortable in your role as tutor.
cons: Some students can be particularly difficult to work with, however, these cases are few and far between.  There is a steep learning curve, but after one semester, things become more comfortable.

pros: I loved working with the undergraduate students helping them with their academic and career goals. Wonderful staff and so many resources. There are great students here as well and many opportunities to get involved on campus.
cons: Lack of faculty, staff and students of color. Also, issues pertaining to racism on campus. Parking can be an issue at times as well.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Durham, NH
pros: Generous stipend through the entire academic year, half of tuition is covered, insurance covered by the university, supervisors make sure to never go over weekly time requirements.
cons: Depending on the program, supervisors won't always have a clear idea of what they will need from assistants. Combination of assistantship and study, while manageable, can be a bit stressful.

job_title: Graduate Student/Research Assistant in Durham, NH
pros: Friendly colleagues. Excellent benefits of working at on University Campus. Small community where you get to know local businesses and they get to know you. Commuter bus system. Amtrak station on campus.
cons: Constant flux of student body. Weekends in Durham are full of rowdy students. Need to drive 15 minutes to get to a small city, at least an hour to get to a real city.

job_title: Peer Assistant Leader in Manchester, NH
pros:
- Easy work
- Make your own hours
- Meet new people, have the opportunity to really expand your network
- Autonomy
cons:
- Pointless mandatory meetings
- Pay is low but expected
- Most PALs are "cut from the same cloth"

review_title: Engineer electrical working with Dr. James Ryan finishing up the Comptel satallite project
pros: A good place to work friendly people I really did not want to leave but it was time to move on
cons: There was no place to eat lunch. Had to go down to the food cart and buy your lunch a wase away

review_title: Atrocious Leadership with Questionable Practices = Turnover
pros:
The students are fantastic across the board. If you're in a role where you get to interact with students you'll really enjoy it. There are plenty of caring co-workers that are in mid-to-lower-level positions--they're awesome to work with.

If you're able to create something or build a strong curriculum for your class, it can be a wonderful experience. As I said, my students were really great to work with including possessing a lot of passion.

Salary can be quite good, although that's relative to your experience. The benefits are really great though especially health insurance. The retirement options are reasonable and comparable to other higher education institutions. Free access to the rec center, computer software, and low-level dental benefits (not necessarily stellar but I wouldn't consider it a con).

Many of my students spoke highly about their experience with the activities (clubs) and their leadership. Also, the Counseling Center (or PACS) and OMSA were spoken highly of by students that I sent that way.

I personally enjoyed the dining hall when I would go for lunch. It's in-house and they take a lot of pride in their work.

The Rec Center is also great between the facilities and staff that run it. Anytime I went to work out there, it was a pleasant experience and my students would share the same experiences.

Lastly, it sounds odd but the UNH Police Chief and the entire staff are awesome! They are always willing to help you out and are a positive influence in our community given the difficulty of their role.
cons:
Unfortunately, there are too many cons to make this a respectable university to work for due to poor leadership. This isn't a problem of "blame the President" or "the Provost doesn't..." which many people tend to do. President Dean has been a breath of fresh air from the tired act of the previous president along with Provost Jones. This really focuses on the leaders that have held positions for far too long and have alienated many individuals and departments across the institution. There are too many backdoor deals where it's clear "favorites" are provided additional resources rather than to pay faculty (some without a contract for over two years while continuing to teach), or to not create bloat within other offices across the institution.

Too many individuals have been forced out of the institution because they would speak their minds and challenge leadership, which their egos did not appreciate. Look at the organizational destruction and dysfunction caused by the current Dean of Students in regards to turnover amongst campus leaders. OMSA has been without a director for 2+ years, which students of color felt discouraged by although the staff they have is great. The Counseling Center became a mess for a few years before the new director finally came (who is also awesome!).

It's obvious that some colleges are provided more support and encouragement from the institution (not just donors) than other colleges, which would bother those of us in those underfunded colleges. For some reason, anything we wanted to do with our students needed to have the approval of the Associate Deans (Ok, fine) and Dean of Students (WHAT?! WHY?!). However, Admissions has no problem asking us to attend extra events they are running outside of our responsibilities without additional compensation.

While my students shared stories of positive interactions with some offices as I mentioned above, they also would stop by to share displeasure with departments like Residence Life and Parking Office. They claimed it wasn't so many issues in the dorms or their roommates but more disappointing interactions with some office staff particularly the director. Several students mentioned inappropriate and condescending comments from her. I shared that with the Dean but have no idea if it was resolved. I could relate to issues with the Parking Office that students mentioned as they handed out tickets constantly when they couldn't even provide enough parking spaces. Students also expressed similar frustrations and interactions with a man named Jeff. You also have to pay for parking as an employee ($75, but it's an open parking lot without additional benefits of security).

pros:
The benefits are very good. Salaries are ok, not the best but not the worst either.
Some great colleagues. The campus itself is beautiful. And I like the students.
cons: Lack of leadership at the department level and a caste system when it comes to tenure/tenure-track vs. non-tenure track faculty. Some people in leadership positions are seriously lacking in common sense and  ethics.

pros: Everyone is willing to give a helping hand pickup hours, Plenty of extra hours to cover if you want more, the people working here are friendly in and out of work, paid CDL B training
cons: Understaffed so there are always hours that need to be covered, underpaid for CDL Bus driving but a very good place to work while in college or just starting out

pros:
Everything about being in University of New Hampshire is amazing. You have a great work life balance and you meet new people everyday and you deal awesome and friendly people.
I have had life changing experiences in this university.
cons: I don't see any down side, except I am city person and University of New Hampshire is located in Durham which is a small town.

pros: Fun work, flexible hours! I have worked a few different jobs on campus, at the CSDC- which was an amazing experience, as well as for various professors. The graduate student rate of pay is much better than the undergrad, which I really appreciated.
cons: On occasion work hours could be more regular- its challenging to constantly be shifting schedules every week / weekend.

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Durham, NH
pros: I had a good work environment and working relationship with my research colleagues . The research I was working on was exciting and engaging.
cons: As funding was allocated through grants, I had limited hours, and the work was primarily grunt work for the graduate students which is in and of itself the nature of the position.

pros: Great environment. I worked in a research lab with 6 other kids. I worked with Polymerase chain reactions for about 20 hours a week. Both the professor and masters student really helped with my understanding of the process while developing my technical lab skills.
cons: There was none in my opinion

pros: I was able to pick my own schedule, out of almost 24 hours in the day. The training department is really thorough and I was got paid to train and get my CDL-B license, which is required for the job.
cons: It is a college, so some rowdy passengers ride the bus sometimes.

pros: the university has good resources, and the people here are really kind and nice. The work is challenging and you can learn a lot from you work.
cons: The challenge of working here is that you need to learn a lot of new things that you have not in the past and you need to take the responsibility sometimes.

review_title: A fun, friendly environment, with people who love their jobs.
job_title: Assistant Lacrosse Coach in Durham, NH
pros: Working as a lacrosse coach was great. There were flexible hours, we had wonderful relationships with the other coaching staff, business center, and administrative departments. Close knit "family" within the University. Very open to help and reach out.
cons: Facilities for athletics was definitely a struggle.

pros:
-Very flexible around your schedule, especially important if you are a college student.
-Good pay compared to other jobs on campus.
-Love the work environment.
-Good experience (CDL B Training)
cons: It doesn't really have any career opportunities, unless you don't mind driving buses for a living.

review_title: A great place to learn a lot from people who know their stuff
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Durham, NH
pros:
Great, friendly people to work with.
Top-notch admin staff and directors who truly care about their workers and the direction of the center.
cons: None that I can think of.

review_title: Worked as Telephone Interviewer, dining assistant, and part of organizations on campus
job_title: Telephone Interviewer, Dining Hall Food Attendant in Durham, NH
pros: great ppl to work with, flexible schedule, on campus so no travel, you know everyone cuz its college campus
cons: limited advances, do the same thing every shift, bit boring, only allow to miss one or two shift per semester

review_title: Research Assistant for over a year
pros: Nice and calm environment, Good work-life balance, Esp. the green environment is an aid for peaceful working environment. Altogether good
cons: There are lots of room for improvement, couple of more STEM research facilities would boost the culture of research and development in this school

review_title: Decent environment, no funding = no raises
pros: Great benefits, good environment most of the time
cons: No raises, no rewards for excellent performance.

pros: Working at the University of New Hampshire is a delight. The people are wonderful and the students are great.
cons: The winters are long and there is a lot of snow, but if you are willing to work with that, this is the place to be.

pros: Challenging work environment that pushed me to grow and become a better individual in the field.
cons: The hours were grueling and pay was minimal. Sometimes appreciation is not shown for word done.

pros: Wonderful support for working parents, great benefits and retirement, supportive and creative culture
cons: Focused on educational degrees for administrative advancement; while not surprising as this is a University, the tuition benefit and pathways for staff to secure degrees while working could be stronger.

review_title: Great place to work.  Lots of dedicated staff who are easy to work with.
pros: Excellent work life balance, autonomy and organization culture.
cons: Pace can be hectic depending on the time of year, but that's to be expected.

pros:
Get paid to get your CDL
Great training process
plenty of room for growth
great coworkers
cons:
Training process takes quite awhile
Need to start early on in college if you want to get any kind of promotion (so get hired as a freshman!)

review_title: Great Employer, Wonderful Management and Co-workers, Inclusive Environment
pros: See Review Title for Pros
cons: Parking, parking, parking...unless you're working around West Edge/Leavitt Lane. Sometimes management listens to you and promises positive change then reverts to same old same old. It's just easier.

pros: Everyone is very friendly and inviting. Office environment is personable and welcoming to their students, faulty and all staff.
cons: The parking in Durham is worse than Boston. I got a ticket for my wheel being on the line of the parking spot.

job_title: Box Office Attendant in Durham, NH
pros: UNH refers to hire work study students, so it was easier for me to get this job
cons: The work is occasionally repetitive

pros: The university is a great and beautiful place to go to school and work.  Not only is it beautiful but with this job you can enjoy
cons: no room for growth in the parking enforcement

review_title: Depending on the teacher you are working with your experience can be great or terrible
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Durham, NH
pros: A teaching positions comes with a complete tuition waiver. You are still responsible for college fees. Health care pay 85% of health costs.
cons: Young graduate students can be easily exploited.

review_title: Worked at the Memorial Union Building as a manager for three years.
pros:
Great management and paid employee development trainings
Established a large network of friends and future professional contacts
cons: Worked late hours on weekends a few times a semester.

review_title: Working full time on the tenure track
pros: The collegial atmosphere, encouragement to try new ideas, friendly people, helpful staff, supportive administration
cons: can be isolating at times depending on where you are on campus, hard to connect with other campus contacts sometimes

pros: help gained knowledge or polymerase chain reaction and electrophoresis, worked with a group of individuals to help grow my knowledge.
cons: there were no cons in working here. I was very fortunate to learn under professor Paul Tsang.

review_title: Worked while pursuing my Master's degree
pros: My supervisor was very understanding, she also made sure to give me major tasks that really helped in improving my abilities and skillset.
cons: I did not have any negative experiences during my time here.

pros: Good students, flexible schedule, good benefits
cons: Incompetent and hostile management, no job security, toxic work culture, union busting

pros: Had amazing bosses when working in the Thompson Hall building
cons: The hours were far too little for a student trying to pay rent and live while going to school

review_title: A good support for a Grad Student
pros: UNH has a good system of managing payments and keeping track of the hours you've worked.
cons: There really aren't many cons to any of the positions available at the University

review_title: Worked at the branch libraries at the University of New Hampshire
job_title: Student Library Assistant in Durham, NH
pros: Very easy job - were allowed to do your homework
cons: Working the weekends wasn't ideal

pros: Great university atmosphere, good benefits.
cons: In need of better overall IT leadership, less politics, more organization will to stay current with IT educational trends and salaries.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Durham, NH
pros: The students, faculty, and staff are very friendly, open to collaboration, and flexible with course offerings
cons: Pay is low, and the workload can be overwhelming depending on the class you teach

pros: At UNH MOA, you get to be surrounded by art created by local artists that is both interesting and inspiring.
cons: I can't think of any downsides to working for this organization.

review_title: Very good position while in school.
pros:
Management is so supportive.
Very flexible work schedule.
Lots of experience to write research papers
Opportunity to give presentations to local CEOs or sponsors
cons: Pay is ok (covers tuition and pays <$2000/mon)

pros: Extremely supportive collaborative research environment, especially in Earth Systems Research Center.
cons: Lots of soft money positions and graduate students are not guaranteed funding, so common feeling of uncertainty about the future funding.

pros: Students are mature and engaged.
cons: Customer service from support staff is not good.

job_title: Student Services Assistant in Durham, NH
pros: Welcoming environment, easy to travel to, students enjoy it so it makes being there better
cons: while its easy to travel to, at times it can seem in the middle of no-where, little diversity

review_title: Learnt in a diverse environment about managing and safety of equipment and lab.
pros: Learning and Earning at the same time.
cons: Not so much helpful for a professional Experience until you are pursuing in teaching career.

job_title: Information Technologist III in Durham, NH
pros: Plenty of paid time off and sick leave if you're PAT staff.  Fantastic retirement matching and decent health insurance.
cons: Even for a university the pay is lower than you'd expect.

review_title: Work Study Job at Registrar's Office
pros: Nice environment to work in, friendly co-workers.
cons: Lots of downtime during less busy times of the year.

pros: Teaching Assistants are given a tuition waiver.
cons: Tread carefully.  Some researchers are unscrupulous and will not give credit, or outright steal, work.

pros:
Get your CDL for free and get paid.
Get to know the sea coast area
Learn every inch of the university campus.
cons:
Always in need of more drivers
Alternating blocks are brutal

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate Chemistry in Durham, NH
pros: Enjoyable area to work and live
cons: Work and connections with other scientists in the area, as well as future employers, can be very limited depending on your supervisor

review_title: Professors Treat RAs and TAs Well but Low Pay
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Durham, NH
pros: Treated well by staff and students. Relatively easy work.
cons: Low pay. Compensation should be higher for the work done.

pros: I like the group i was working with, my supervisor and coworker and also the project i was workking was so exciting
cons: I loved working in UNH, there was no cons

pros: Best benefit package around, working with students, yearly 1% raise
